Text: Governor Walker, I want to go to you. Dr. Carson wants to raise the Federal Minimum Wage, you have called it a lame idea. Why is raising the Federal Minimum Wage lame?

Speaker: WALKER
Text: So, the best way to help people see their wages go up is to get them the education, the skill they need, to take on careers that pay more than minimum wage. And, it's why we talk about it, it's all about jobs. You want to help actually get jobs, it's why on that last question we were trying to jump in on taxes. To me, it's not just about taxes, cutting taxes. I've done it as much as anyone has.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: I've cut income taxes, I've cut property taxes. In fact, property taxes are lower today in my state than they were before we took office. The real issues about jobs.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: Ronald Reagan, our plan is based on the Ronald Reagan tax cuts of 1986. That brought about one of the longest sustained periods of economic growth in American history. All the things we should be talking about tonight are about how do we create jobs, helping people get the skills and the education qualifications they need to succeed.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: That's the way you help people create jobs. It's part of our large plan to reform the tax code, to cut taxes, to put in place an education system that gives people the skills and education that they need. To put in place all the above energy policy, but you start on day one with repealing Obamacare.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: I'm the only one on this stage that's actually got a plan, introduced an actual plan to repeal Obamacare on day one. I'll send a bill up to Congress, and to make sure enact it...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Thank you, Governor...

Speaker: WALKER
Text: ...I'm going to sign an order that makes the Congress live by the same rules as everybody else. TAPPER: ...Thank you, Governor...

Speaker: WALKER
Text: ...That will ensure they repeal Obamacare...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. Carson, Governor Walker didn't really answer the question, but I'll let you respond. He called raising the Federal Minimum Wage lame, what do you think of that?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Well, first of all, let me say what I actually said about raising the minimum wage. I was asked should it be raised, I said, probably, or possibly. But, what I added, which I think is the most important thing, so, I said we need to get both sides of this issue to sit down, and talk about it. Negotiate a reasonable minimum wage, and index that so that we never have to have this conversation again in the history of America.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: I think we also have to have two minimum wages, a starter, and a sustaining because how are young people ever going to get a job if you have such a high minimum wage that it makes it impractical to hire them...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Dr. Carson...

Speaker: WALKER
Text: ...Jake, Jake, Jake, I just want to address that issue because you said I didn't answer, and I did. I said, to me, I think the real focus shouldn't be - you know, Hillary Clinton talks about the minimum wage. That's her answer to grow the economy. The answer is to give people the skills and the education so they make far more than minimum wage.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: I don't want to argue about how low things are going to be, I want to talk about how do we lift everyone up in America. That's what Reagan talked about. It wasn't how bad things were, it was how to make it better for everyone. That's what we've done in Wisconsin, that's exactly what we'd do as...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Let me bring in our partner from Salem Radio Network, Hugh Hewitt.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: I'd like to talk about winning because I think all of you are more qualified than former Secretary of State Clinton, and as were the people in the first debate, but there are different styles, and Carly Fiorina, Governor Kasich, you're conveniently located next to each other, and you have different styles.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Governor Kasich, you've been on my show a lot. You refused to attack Hillary Clinton, you just don't want to go there, you want to do the up with people. Go, Ohio, OK, and I like that.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Carly Fiorina, I don't have to bring up the Secretary of State - you bring her up, so (inaudible).

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Which one of you is wrong? Governor Kasich?

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Well, look, people still have to get to know me, so I want to spend my time talking about my experience reforming welfare, balancing budgets, cutting taxes, providing economic growth when I was in Washington, turning Ohio around. Eight billion in the hole, $2 billion surplus, up over 300,000 jobs, big tax cuts, strengthening our credit.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: All those things matter but, you know, as a young man in my first election in 1978, I defeated an incumbent Democrat. I defeated an incumbent Democrat in 1982; running on the Reagan program, I was the only Republican in America to defeat an incumbent Democrat that year.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: And then, when I won for election of governor, I was the first Republican to defeat an incumbent in 36 years, and the first person to have never run statewide out of politics for 10 years to beat an incumbent. That hadn't happened for 96 years.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: So, we'll get to the point where we'll talk about Hillary Clinton, or whoever the nominee is, record. But right now, I want to give people sense of hope, sense of purpose, a sense of unity, sense that we can do it. So...

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Governor.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: You know, at the end of the day, I'm going to continue to talk about my record, because there is, did you ever notice when people run for office, they run for president, they make a lot of promises, they don't keep them.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Governor. KASICH: I don't intend to do that, and I going to be out there pushing it out - don't worry about me and Hillary. That will all work out, and I'm from Ohio. She will not beat me there, I can promise you that.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Carly Fiorina, your style?

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: You see, Governor Christie, people spend time talking about their track records, and Mr. Trump and I have every right to do the same. And Mrs. Clinton has to defend her track record.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Her track record of lying about Benghazi, of lying about her e- mails, about lying about her servers. She does not have a track record of accomplishment.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Like Mrs. Clinton, I, too, have travels hundreds of thousands of miles around the globe. But unlike Mrs. Clinton, I know flying is an activity, not an accomplishment. Mrs. Clinton - if you want to stump a Democrat, ask them to name a accomplishment of Mrs. Clinton's.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Governor Christie, your name was mentioned. I want to give you a chance to respond.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Listen, you know, Hugh, it's an important point. And the question is, who is going to prosecute Hillary Clinton?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: The Obama White House seems to have in interest, the Justice Department seems to have no interest. I think it's time to put a former federal prosecutor on the same stage as Hillary Clinton.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And I will prosecute her during those debates on that stage for the record we're talking about here. The fact she had a private email server in her basement, using national security secrets running through it, could have been hacked by the Russians, the Chinese, or two 18-year-olds on a toot (ph) wanting to have some fun.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: No one is answering that question from the Hillary Clinton campaign...

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: You know why? Because she knows she's wrong, and she cannot look in the mirror at herself, and she cannot tell the American people the truth.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Governor Christie. There is a lot more coming up.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Ahead, a world of trouble. The challenges that one of these candidates may face in the Oval Office, and how he or she will handle it.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Stay with us.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Welcome back to CNN's Republican Presidential Debate. Let's turn to some issues now in foreign policy.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump, Senator Rubio said it was, quote, "very concerning to him" that in a recent interview you didn't seem to know the details about some of the enemies the U.S. faces. Rubio said, if you don't know the answers to those questions, you will not be able to serve as commander-in-chief.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Please respond to Senator Rubio.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, I heard Hugh Hewitt, a nice man, he apologized because he actually said that we had a misunderstanding. And he said today that Donald Trump is maybe the best interview there is anywhere that he has ever done.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Now unless he was just saying that on CNN to be nice, but he did say that...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Oh, you're the best interview in America.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And we had a legitimate misunderstanding in terms of his pronunciation of a word.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But I would say just...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, I think it was. And he actually said that. Did you say that?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: ... makes an interesting case (ph) here (ph).

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: OK. So I will say this, though, Hugh was giving me name after name, Arab name, Arab name, and there are few people anywhere, anywhere that would have known those names. I think he was reading them off a sheet.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And frankly I will have - and I told him, I will have the finest team that anybody has put together and we will solve a lot of problems.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: You know, right now they know a lot and look at what is happening. The world is blowing up around us. We will have great teams and great people.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Rubio?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I hope that answers your question. I mean, you are in the Senate, but I hope that answers your question.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Yes, well, it does. But it's in the following way, this is an important question. I think if you're running for president, these are important issues, because look at around the world today.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: There is a lunatic in North Korea with dozens of nuclear weapons and long-range rocket that can already hit the very place in which we stand tonight. The Chinese are rapidly expanding their military. They hack into our computers. They're building artificial islands in the South China Sea, the most important shipping lane in the world.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: A gangster in Moscow is not just threatening Europe, he's threatening to destroy and divide NATO. You have radical jihadists in dozens of countries across multiple continents. And they even recruit Americans using social media to try to attack us here at home.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And now we have got this horrible deal with Iran where a radical Shia cleric with an apocalyptic vision of the future is also guaranteed to one day possess nuclear weapons and also a long-range rocket that can hit the United States.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: These are extraordinarily dangerous times that we live in. And the next president of the United States better be someone that understands these issues and has good judgment about them because the number one issue that a president will ever confront, and the most important obligation that the federal government has, is to keep this nation safe.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And today we are not doing that. We are eviscerating our military. And we have a president that is more respectful to the ayatollah in Iran than he is to the prime minister of Israel.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump? Senator Rubio seemed to be suggesting that you don't know information that...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: No, I don't think he's suggesting that at all. I mean...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: All right. Senator Rubio.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I don't think he's suggesting that at all.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Well, that's why we have a debate. I think that we should have a deeper debate about these issues, because there is no more important decision that a president will make.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: But are you saying that you have the knowledge to be the president that Mr. Trump does not have?

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Well, you should ask him questions in detail about the foreign policy issues our president will confront, because you had better be able to lead our country on the first day.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Not six months from now, not a year from now, on the first day in office, our president could very well confront a national security crisis. You can't predict it. Sometimes you cannot control it.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And it is the most - the federal government does all kinds of things it's not supposed to be doing. It regulates bathrooms. It regulates schools that belong to local communities.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: But the one thing that the federal government must do, the one thing that only the federal government can do is keep us safe. And a president better be up-to-date on those issues on his first day in office, on her first day in office.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, you have to understand, I am not sitting in the United States Senate with, by the way, the worst voting record there is today. Number one. I am not sitting in the United States Senate. I'm a businessman doing business transactions.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Trust (ph) me, I get that. OK.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I am doing business transactions. I will know more about this - and, as you said, that was very acceptable, and when you listen to that whole interview, it's a great interview, you said it, I didn't. Well, now I did. But...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Listen, just one second. Just one second.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: I never get to addressed, and...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I will know...

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: ...and when I do, I'm gonna jump in.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ...I will know more about the problems of this world by the time I sit, and you look at what's going in this world right now by people that supposedly know, this world is a mess. TAPPER: Senator Rubio, he did invoke your absentee record in the Senate.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Yeah. He did. Let me - I'm proud to serve in the United States Senate. You know, when I ran five years ago, the entire leadership of my party in Washington lined up against me.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: But I'm glad I won. And I'm glad that I ran, because this country's headed in the wrong direction. And if we keep electing the same people, nothing is going to change.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And you're right, I have missed some votes, and I'll tell you why, Mr. Trump. Because in my years in the Senate, I've figured out very quickly that the political establishment in Washington, D.C. in both political parties is completely out of touch with the lives of our people.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: You have millions of people in this country living paycheck to paycheck, and nothing is being done about it. We are about to leave our children with $18 trillion in - in - in debt, and they're about to raise the debt limit again.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: We have a world that grows increasingly dangerous, and we are eviscerating our military spending and signing deals with Iran. And these - if this thing continues, we are going to be the first Americans to leave our children worse off than ourselves.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: That's why I'm missing votes. Because I am leaving the Senate, I'm not running for re-election, and I'm running for president because I know this unless we have the right president, we cannot make America fulfill its potential, but with the right person in office, the 21st century can be the greatest era that our nation has ever known.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator Rubio. I want to turn now to Hugh Hewitt.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Jake. I've done a lot of great interviews with all of you, but, Governor Bush, I talked to you in February about the biggest elephant in a room full of elephants, which is your last name. And you said you would not be burdened either by your brother or your father's legacy in the Middle East.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: And then, a week later, you rolled out your list of foreign policy advisers, and it was a lot of the band getting back together again. So on behalf of the military that is watching...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: ...OK, the active duty military that are at the end of the sphere (ph), what kind of a commander in chief is Jeb Bush going to be, and who are the advisers that are new to your team?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, first of all, Hugh, if you're looking at Republican advisers, you have to go to the last two administrations. That happened to be 41 and 43. So just by definition, if you're - and many of the people here that are seeking advice from the foreign policy experts in the Republican side, they - they served in my dad's administration, my brother's administration. Of course that's the case.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: But I'm my own man. I'm going to create a strategy that is based on the simple fact that the United States needs to lead the world. The first thing that we need to do is to stop the craziness of the sequester.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Rebuild our military so that our - so that we don't deploy people over and over again without the necessary equipment to keep them safe, to send a signal to the world that we're serious. If we're going to lead the world, then we need to have the strongest military possible.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: We need to rebuild our counterintelligence and intelligence capabilities. We need to focus on the fact that the next president is going to start in 2017, not in 1990 - you know, 30 years ago, or when my brother started.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: The world is dramatically different. And I believe that we need to restore America's presence and leadership in the world. Name a country where our relationship is better today than it was the - the day that Barack Obama got elected president.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Under Hillary Clinton, and Barack Obama, we have seen a weakness that now creates huge problems for the next president of the United States. So I'll have a team that will be - that will be following the doctrine I set up, and it will be peace through strength.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: We're sitting here in this library, which is a wonderful place to talk about this, because that's exactly what happened in the 1980s, and the world was a lot safer because of...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (inaudible)

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Mr. - Mr. Trump.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: The leadership of Ronald Reagan and my...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: I want to ask you a question, though, you promised us great leaders. And I believe that. But Jeb Bush has laid out 20 different people that have experience around the world. There are 190 countries, you can't run the world by yourself.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: When are we going to get some names on your military and your foreign policy advisers?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (inaudible) I'm - and I'm meeting with people that are terrific people, but I have to say something because it's about judgment.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I am the only person on this dais - the only person - that fought very, very hard against us (ph), and I wasn't a sitting politician going into Iraq, because I said going into Iraq - that was in 2003, you can check it out, check out - I'll give you 25 different stories.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: In fact, a delegation was sent to my office to see me because I was so vocal about it. I'm a very militaristic person, but you have to know when to use the military. I'm the only person up here that fought against going into Iraq.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Hugh, can I - can I make a response to that?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Just excuse me, one second, Rand...

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Can I make a response to that?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: If you don't mind, Rand - you know, you are on last - you do have your 1 percent.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I would like - and I think it's very important. I think it's important, because it's about judgment. It's about judgment.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I didn't want to go into Iraq, and I fought it, because what I said - what I said...

Speaker: PAUL
Text: May I make a response to that?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ... was you're going to - you're going to destabilize...

Speaker: PAUL
Text: He's referred to me.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: ... the Middle East, and that's what happened.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: He's referred to me...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: So you - the - the first chance...

Speaker: PAUL
Text: ... in his remarks. May I make a response?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Right after me, and then I'll - I'll yield - yield the floor. What do you guys say in the Senate when you're talking and debating?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Absolutely. Go ahead.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Here's the facts: When Donald Trump talks about judgment, what was his position on who would've been the best negotiator to deal with Iran? It wasn't a Republican; it was Hillary Clinton. That's what you believe. I mean, the lack of judgment and the lack of understanding about how the world works is really dangerous in this kind of time that we're saying.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: So is that the judgment that you bring to the table, that Hillary Clinton...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: If you think about it...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: ... is a great negotiator, that she could bring about a better deal on Iran?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Your brother - and your brother's administration gave us Barack Obama, because it was such a disaster, those last three months, that Abraham Lincoln couldn't have been elected.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: You know what? As it relates to my brother, there's one thing I know for sure. He kept us safe.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I don't know if you remember...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: BUSH
Text: ... Donald...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: BUSH
Text: ... you remember the - the rumble? You remember the fire fighter with his arms around it? He sent a clear signal that the United States would be strong and fight Islamic terrorism, and he did keep us safe.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I don't know. You feel safe right now? I don't feel so safe.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: May I respond?

Speaker: WALKER
Text: That's because of Barack - that's because of Barack Obama.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: That's - that's my brother.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: That's because of Barack Obama. We've had a president who called ISIS the J.V. squad, Yemen a success story, Iran a place we can do business with. It's not because of George W. Bush; it's because of Barack Obama...

Speaker: WALKER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: WALKER
Text: (inaudible) on that point, though, whether it's - whether we're talking about national security, foreign policy or we're talking about domestic policy, the key...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Or the collapse of the economy.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: ... the key issue here is talking about leadership. Now, there's a lot of greater people up here, and you've heard a lot of great ideas out there. But I would ask the American people, look at who's been tested.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: When there were 100,000 protesters in my capital, I didn't back down, when they issued death threats against me and threats against my family, I didn't back down, when they tried to recall me, I didn't back down, and when they made me the - one of their number-one targets last year, I didn't back down.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: Give me the chance to be your president.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: I won't back down...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator...

Speaker: WALKER
Text: ... on any of these issues.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Paul?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: The remark was made that there hadn't been anyone else on the podium opposed to the Iraq War. I've made my career as being an opponent of the Iraq War. I was opposed to the Syria war. I was opposed to arming people who are our enemies.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Iran is now stronger because Hussein is gone. Hussein was the great bulwark and counterbalance to the Iranians. So when we complain about the Iranians, you need to remember that the Iraq War made it worse.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Originally, Governor Bush was asked, was the Iraq War a mistake, and he said, "No. We'd do it again."

Speaker: PAUL
Text: We have to learn sometimes the interventions backfire. The Iraq War backfired and did not help us. We're still paying the repercussions of a bad decision.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Paul...

Speaker: PAUL
Text: We have make the decision now in Syria, should we topple Assad? Many up here wanted to topple Assad, and it's like - I said no, because if you do...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator Paul...

Speaker: PAUL
Text: ... ISIS will now be in charge of Syria...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator Paul...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I understand that Governor Bush's name has been invoked, and then we can go to you, Senator Rubio. BUSH: Here's the lessons of history: When we - we pull back, voids are created. We left Iraq. We should've had a - a forces agreement to stay there with a small force, and instead of that, we politically and militarily pulled back, and now we have the creation of ISIS.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: 36 days ago in this very library, I gave a speech with a comprehensive strategy how to take out ISIS, and it requires American leadership and engagement. We don't have to be the world's policemen. But we certainly have to be the world's leader.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: We need to have - make sure that the world knows that we're serious, that we're engaged, that we're not going to pull back, that - that our - that our word matters. And if we do that, we can create a force that will take out ISIS both in Iraq and in Syria, which will take a lot longer time now...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: ... because of what President Obama's done by pulling back.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Rubio?

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: I want to go even deeper - and I want to go even deeper in that direction, because I think the belief that somehow by retreating, America makes the world safer has been disproven every single time it's ever been tried.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Syria's a perfect example of it. The uprising in Syria was not started by the United States; it was started by the Syrian people. And I warned at the time - this was three and a half years ago - I openly and repeatedly warned that if we did not find moderate elements on the ground that we could equip and arm, that void would be filled by radical jihadists.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Well, the president didn't listen, the administration didn't follow through, and that's exactly what happened. That is why ISIS grew. That is why ISIS then came over the border from Syria and back into Iraq.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: What is happening in that region is the direct consequence of the inability to lead and of disengagement. And the more we disengage, the more airplanes from Moscow you're going to see flying out of Damascus and out of Syria...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: ... as you asked earlier today.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Jake, Jake...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. Carson?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: I haven't had an opportunity to weigh in on foreign policy, and I just want to mention that when the war, when the issue occurred in 2003, I suggested to President Bush that he not go to war? OK. So I just want that on the record.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: And, you know, a lot of people are very much against us getting involved right now with global jihadism. And they refer back to our invasion of Iraq. And they seem to think that that was what caused it.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: What caused it was withdrawing from there and creating a vacuum which allowed this terrible situation to occur. But it is very different from what is going on today. We're talking about global jihadists who actually want to destroy us.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: They are an existential threat to our nation. And we have to be mature enough to recognize that our children will have no future if we put our heads in the sand. We have to recognize we have two choices.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: We either allow them the continue to progress and appear to be the winners, or we use every resource available to us to destroy...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Dr. Carson.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: ... them first.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I mean, it is interesting that you say that, because I want to ask Governor Christie about something else that you have said.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Christie, we just marked the 14th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. Now Dr. Carson has said that if he had been president at the time, the United States would not have gone to war in Afghanistan. What does that say to you about how Dr. Carson would respond as president if America were attacked again?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Well, Jake, I was named U.S. attorney by President Bush on September 10th, 2001. And that next day my wife Mary Pat did what she did every day, she traveled through the World Trade Center and went to her office two blocks from the World Trade Center.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And after those planes hit, for five-and-a-half-hours after that, I couldn't reach her, didn't know whether she was dead or alive, and we had three children at the time, 8, 5 and 1.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And I had to confront what so many thousands of others in my region had to confront, the idea I might become a single parent, the idea that my life and my children's life might be changed forever.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: We lost friends that day. We went to the funerals. And I will tell you that what those people wanted and what they deserved was for America to answer back against what had been done to them.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And I support what President Bush did at that time, going into Afghanistan, hunting al Qaeda and its leaders, getting its sanctuary out of place, and making it as difficult around the world for them to move people and money.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And then he went to prosecutors like us, and he said, never again. Don't prosecute these people after the crime is committed. Intervene before the crime happens. I absolutely believe that what the president did at the time was right.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And I am proud to have been one of the people on the stage who was part of making sure that what Governor Bush said before was the truth. America was safe for those seven years and Barack Obama has taken that safety away from us.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. Carson?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Well, recognize that, you know, President George W. Bush is a great friend of ours, and we spent many wonderful days at the White House. I haven't been there in the last seven years. I probably have to have a food-tester.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: CARSON
Text: But at any rate, I didn't suggest that nothing be done. What I suggested to President Bush is to be Kennedy-esque, in the sense that when the Russians got ahead of us in the space race, what we did is use the bully pulpit to galvanize everybody, business, industry, academia behind a national goal to put a man on the moon and bring him back safely.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: I said, you can do the same kind of thing. Declare that within five to 10 years we will become petroleum independent. The moderate Arab states would have been so concerned about that, they would have turned over Osama bin Laden and anybody else you wanted on a silver platter within two weeks.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: There are smart ways to do things and there are muscular ways to do things. And sometimes you have to look at both of those to come up with the right solution.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ... Governor Christie.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Let me say this, Jake, is that while that may have been a fine idea that Dr. Carson had, these people were out to kill us.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I stood in that region with my family, and every time a plane went overhead in the weeks after that, people's heads jerked to the sky because they thought it was happening again.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: You do not need to go through subtle diplomacy at that point. That could be handled later on. What you need is a strong American leader who will take the steps that are necessary to protect our nation.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: That's what I would do as commander-in-chief in this circumstance. And that's what President George W. Bush did in 2001.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. Carson?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: I have no argument with having a strong leader, and to be aggressive where aggression is needed. But it is not needed in every circumstance. There is a time when you can use your intellect to come up with other ways to do things. And I think that's what we have to start thinking about.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: There is no question that a lot of these problems that we have been talking about in terms of the international situation is because we are weak. It is because our Navy is so small. It is because our Air Force is incapable of doing the same things that it did a few years ago.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: It's because our Marines Corps is not ready to be deployed.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Dr. Carson.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: There are a lot of problems that are going on, and we need to solve those problems, we need to build up our military...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Dr. Carson.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: But radical terrorism cannot be solved by intellect. It cannot - they require - what they need, is they need an operating space. That's what Afghanistan was for Al Qaida. It was a vacuum that they filled, and they created an operating space.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: That's why they had to be drawn out of there. That's why they had to be destroyed. It is the reason why ISIS has grown as well. We allowed them - we allowed a vacuum to emerge in Syria. They used it as an operating space to grow; and today they're not just in Iraq and Syria anymore, they're now in Libya, conducting operations in the Sinai.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: They're now in Afghanistan, trying to supplant the Taliban as the most powerful radical jihadist group on the ground there, as well. You cannot allow radical jihadists to have an operating safe haven anywhere in the world.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Huckabee.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: Just today - just today, there was a new report that 50 different intelligence analysts have said that what they sent up the ladder was doctored by senior officials, so that they could give some happy talk to the situation that we face.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: I love the idea of a good intellectual capacity to deal with our enemies, but the fact is, if you don't have good intelligence that is reliable and honest, you won't have good intelligence and you cannot make good decisions.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: The next president is primarily elected not just to know things, but to know what to do with the things that he knows. And the most dangerous person in any room is the person who doesn't know what he doesn't know.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: And the reason Barack Obama has been dangerous to this country and we better elect someone who had some executive experience, is because we cannot afford another eight years having a person in the office who doesn't know what he does not know.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, governor, I want to turn to ISIS. Governor Walker...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We just spent - we just spent the last 10 minutes...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Walker, there is a big debate now, we have been talking about ISIS here and there in this discussion, there a big debate right now about whether or not to send more U.S. troops to fight ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: In the first debate earlier this evening, Senator Lindsey Graham argued that candidates are only serious about fighting ISIS if they're willing to send 10,000 U.S. troops to Iraq, 10,000 U.S. troops as part of a coalition to Syria.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Walker, you say, you just told me a few days ago that the 3,000 U.S. troops there right now are enough, as long as the rules of engagement are changed.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: What do you know that Senator Graham doesn't know?

Speaker: WALKER
Text: To be clear, what I said the other day was that we need to lift the political restrictions that are already in play. Barack Obama's administration has put political restrictions on the military personnel already in Iraq.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: We need to lift those and then we need to listen to our military experts, not the political forces in the White House, but our military experts about how many more we sent in. And we certainly shouldn't have a commander-in-chief who sends a message to our adversaries as to how far we're going to go, and how far we're willing to fight, so I'm not putting a troop number.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: What I'm saying is lift the political restrictions. When you do that, you empower our military personnel already there to work with the Kurd and the Sunni allies, to reclaim the territory taken by ISIS. And to do so in a way that allows that ISIS doesn't go back in Syria, as we were just talking about here.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: That is the fundamental problem going forward. We have a president - and Hillary Clinton was a part of this, by the way, who has made political decisions for our men and women in uniform. I want the men and women at home to know, if I'm commander-in-chief, I will only send you into harm's way when our national security is at risk. And if we do, you know you'll have our full support, the support of the American people, and you'll have a clear path for victory.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Paul, I want to go to you, because you have said that the boots on the ground to fight ISIS need to be Arab boots. We just learned today that despite the Obama administration spending $500 million to help create those Arab boots, there are only four or five U.S. trained fighters in Syria fighting ISIS.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: What does that say to you about the effectiveness of the idea of the boots on the ground need to be Arab boots?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: If you want boots on the ground, and you want them to be our sons and daughters, you got 14 other choices. There will always be a Bush or Clinton for you, if you want to go back to war in Iraq.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: But the thing is, the first war was a mistake. And I'm not sending our sons and our daughters back to Iraq. The war didn't work. We can amplify those who live there.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: The Kurds deserve to be armed and I'll arm them. We can use our Air Force to amplify the forces there. But the boots on the ground need to be the people who live there.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: My goodness, I'm still upset with the Saudi Arabians for everything they do over there. They've funded the arms that went to the jihadists. They're not accepting any of the people, any of the migrants that have been - the refugees that are being pushed out of Syria. Saudi Arabia is not accepting one.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Why are we always the world's patsies that we have to go over there and fight their wars for them? They need to fight their wars, we need to defend American interests, but it is not in America's national security interests to have another war in Iraq.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: We're going to turn to some domestic issues now. I want to bring in my colleague, Dana Bash.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Can I just - can I - Jake, can I just make one point on this whole military discussion?

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Sure....

Speaker: KASICH
Text: I called for boots on the ground many months ago in a coalition with our friends who share our interest. You know, you win a battle with the military, and when we go somewhere, we need to be mobile, and lethal. We need to take care of business, and we need to come home.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: But, we face, also, a bigger war - and you win the bigger war with the battle of ideas. You wonder why young people, and educated people, rich people, schooled people, have tried to join ISIS.

Speaker: KASICH
Text: Western civilization, all of us, need to wake up to the fact that those murderers and rapists need to be called out, and in Western civilization we need to make it clear that our faith in the Jewish and Christian principals force us to live a life bigger than ourselves...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Thank you, Governor...

Speaker: KASICH
Text: ...to make (ph) centers (ph) of justice so that we can battle the radicals, call them out for what they are, and make sure that all of our people feel fulfilled in living in Western civilization...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Thank you, Governor. Dana Bash...

Speaker: KASICH
Text: ...This is a giant battle in the world today...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...Jake, since everyone has gotten to weigh in on this military issue, I'd like to be able to do the same.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We have spent probably 12 minutes talking about the past. Let's talk about the future. We need the strongest military on the face of the planet, and everyone has to know it. And, specifically, what that means is we need about 50 Army brigades, we need about 36 Marine battalions, we need somewhere between 300, and 350 naval ships, we need to upgrade every leg of the nuclear triad...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Mrs. Fiorina...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...we need to reform the Department of Defense, we need as well...

Speaker: BASH
Text: ...Thank you....

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Thank you, we're going to turn now to domestic issues with Dana Bash.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...to invest in our military technology, and we need to care for our veterans so 307,000...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Dana Bash...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: ...aren't dying waiting for health care.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you. (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dana Bash?

Speaker: BASH
Text: Governor Bush, let's talk about the issue that's very important to Republican voters, and that's the Supreme Court. After Chief Justice John Roberts voted to uphold Obamacare twice, Senator Cruz criticized your brother for appointing John Roberts to the Supreme Court.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Looking back on it, did your brother make a mistake?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, I'm surprised Senator Cruz would say that since he was as strong supporter of John Roberts at the time.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I will talk about what I will do as it relates to appointing Supreme Court Justices. We need to make sure that we have justices that, with a proven experienced record of respect for upholding the constitution. That is what we need. We can't have - the history in recent past is appoint people that have no experience so that you can't get attacked.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And, that makes it harder for people to have confidence that they won't veer off...

Speaker: BASH
Text: ...Is John Roberts one of those people?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: John Roberts has made some really good decisions, for sure, but he did not have a proven, extensive record that would have made the clarity the important thing, and that's what we need to do. And, I'm willing to fight for those nominees to make sure that they get passed. You can't do it the politically expedient way anymore. This is the culture in Washington. You have to fight hard for these appointments. This is perhaps the most important thing that the next president will do.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Do you like what you just heard, Senator Cruz?

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Well, Dana, I've known John Roberts for 20 years, he's amazingly talented lawyer, but, yes, it was a mistake when he was appointed to the Supreme Court. He's a good enough lawyer that he knows in these Obamacare cases he changed the statute, he changed the law in order to force that failed law on millions of Americans for a political outcome.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: And, you know, we're frustrated as conservatives. We keep winning elections, and then we don't get the outcome we want. And, let me focus on two moments in time.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: Number one, in 1990, in one room was David Souter, and in another room was Edith Jones, the rock ribbed (ph) conservative on the fifth circuit court of appeals. George Herbert Walker Bush appointed David Souter.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: And then in 2005, in one room was John Roberts, in another room was my former boss, Mike Luttig, the rock ribbed (ph) conservative on the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ...George W. Bush appointed John Roberts, and let me give you the consequences of that.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: If, instead, the President Bush had appointed Edith Jones, and Mike Luttig, which is who I would have appointed, Obamacare would have been struck down three years ago, and the marriage laws of all 50 states would be on the books. These matter, and I fought to defend the constitution my whole life...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...Governor Bush...

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ...and I will as president as well.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...I want to let you respond.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, first of all, he, as I said, supported John Roberts. He supported him, publicly. So, you can rewrite history, I guess, Ted, but the simple fact is that you supported him because he had all the criteria that you would have thought would have made a great justice. And, I think he is doing a good job.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: But, the simple fact is that going forward, what we need to do is to have someone that has a long standing set of rulings that consistently makes it clear that he is a focused, exclusively on upholding the Constitution of the United States so they won't try to use the bench as a means to which legislate.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...And, that's what we should do, and I hope I'll be working members of the United States Senate to fight hard for the passage of people that have that kind of qualification.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Cruz, 30 seconds.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: It is true that after George W. Bush nominated John Roberts, I supported his confirmation. That was a mistake and I regret that. I wouldn't have nominated John Roberts, and indeed, Governor Bush pointed out why.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: It wasn't that the President Bushes wanted to appoint a liberal to the court, it's that it was the easier choice. Both David Souter and John Roberts, they didn't have a long paper trail. If you had nominated Edith Jones or Mike Ludig (ph) you would have had a bloody fight and they weren't willing to spend political capital to put a strong judicial conservative on the court.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: I have spent my entire life, starting from clerking for Chief Justice William Rehnquist on the United States Supreme Court, one of the most principled jurists. We have an out-of-control Court, and I give you my word, if I'm elected president, every single Supreme Court justice will faithfully follow the law and will not act like philosopher kings -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: - imposing their liberal policies on millions of Americans -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Semator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: - who need to be trusted to govern ourselves.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Huckabee, I want to bring you in very quickly if you could. Will you have a litmus test when it comes to appointing Supreme Court nominees?

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: You better believe I will, because I'm tired of liberals always having a litmus test and conservatives are supposed to pretend we don't. Well let me tell you what mine would be.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: Number one, I'd ask do you think that the unborn child is a human being or is it just a blob of tissue? I'd want to know the answer to that. I'd want to know do you believe in the First Amendment, do you believe that religious liberty is the fundamental liberty around which all the other freedoms of this country are based? And I'd want to know do you really believe in the Second Amendment, do you believe that we have an individual right to bear arms to protect ourselves and our family and to protect our country? And do you believe in the Fifth and the 14th Amendment? Do you believe that a person, before they're deprived of life and liberty, should in fact have due process and equal protection under the law? Because if you do, you're going to do more than defund Planned Parenthood.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: One final thing. I'd make darn sure that we absolutely believe the 10th Amendment. Every governor on this stage would share this much with you. Every one of us - our biggest fight wasn't always with the legislature or even with the Democrats. My gosh, half the time, it was with the federal government who apparently never understood -

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: HUCKABEE
Text: - that if it's not reserved in the Constitution, then the 10th Amendment says it's left to the states. But somebody forgot to send a memo to Washington.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor. We're going to take a quick break. Coming up, one of the hottest questions that you have been asking us via social media. We will pose it to the candidates. That's coming up right after this.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Welcome back to CNN's Republican presidential debate at the Reagan Library here in Simi Valley - Simi Valley, California.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Many people on social media wanted us to ask about marijuana legalization. Senator Paul, Governor Christie recently said, quote, "if you're getting high in Colorado today," where marijuana has been legalized, "enjoy it until January 2017, because I will enforce the federal laws against marijuana." Will you?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: I think one of the great problems, and what American people don't like about politics, is hypocrisy. People have one standard for others and not for them - for themselves.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: There is at least one prominent example on the stage of someone who says they smoked pot in high school, and yet the people going to - to jail for this are poor people, often African-Americans and often Hispanics, and yet the rich kids who use drugs aren't.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: I personally think that this is a crime for which the only victim is the individual, and I think that America has to take a different attitude. I would like to see more rehabilitation and less incarceration. I'm a fan of the drug courts which try to direct you back towards work and less time in jail.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: But the bottom line is the states. We say we like the 10th Amendment, until we start talking about this. And I think the federal government has gone too far, I think that the war on drugs has had a racial outcome, and really has been something that has really damaged our inner cities.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Not only do the drugs damage them, we damage them again by incarcerating them and then preventing them from getting employment over time.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: So I don't think that the federal government should override the states. I believe in the 10th Amendment and I really will say that the states are left to themselves.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to give that - I want to give the person that you called a hypocrite an opportunity to respond. Do you want to identify that person?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Well, I think if we left it open, we could see how many people smoked pot in high school.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Is there somebody you were specifically thinking of?

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Well, you know, the thing is that...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: He was talking about me.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Yeah, I was talking about (inaudible) - well, let me...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: That's what I though, but I wanted (inaudible) to say it.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, I - I wanted to - be - make it easier for him.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: OK.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And I just did.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Bush, please.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: So, 40 years ago, I smoked marijuana, and I admit it. I'm sure that other people might have done it and may not want to say it in front of 25 million people. My mom's not happy that I just did.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: BUSH
Text: That's true. And here's the deal. Here's the deal. We have - we have a serious epidemic of drugs that goes way beyond marijuana. What goes on in Colorado, as far as I'm concerned, that should be a state decision.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: But if you look at the problem of drugs in this - in this society today, it's a serious problem. Rand, you know this because you're campaigning in New Hampshire like all of us, and you see the epidemic of heroin, the overdoses of heroin that's taking place.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: People's families are - are being torn apart. It is appropriate for the government to play a consistent role to be able to provide more treatment, more prevention - we're the state that has the most drug courts across every circuit in - in - in Florida, there are drug courts to give people a second chance.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: That's the best way to do this.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: But let me respond. The thing is, is that in Florida, Governor Bush campaigned against medical marijuana. That means that a small child like Morgan Hintz (ph) that has seizures is day, is failing on non-traditional medications, is not allowed to use cannabis oil.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: And if they do that in Florida, they will take the child away, they will put the parents in jail. And that's what that means if you're against allowing people use medical marijuana, you'll actually put them in jail.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: No, you're wrong - you're wrong about this.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: And actually, under the current circumstances, kids who had privilege like you do, don't go to jail, but the poor kids in our inner cities go to jail. I don't think that's fair. And I think we need to acknowledge it, and it is hypocritical to still want to put poor people in jail... BUSH: I don't want to put poor people in jail, Randy.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Well, you vote - you oppose medical marijuana...

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Here's the deal. No, I did not oppose when the legislature passed the bill to deal with that very issue. That's the way to solve this problem.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Medical marijuana on the ballot was opened up, there was a huge loophole, it was the first step to getting to a (inaudible) place. And as a citizen of Florida, I voted no.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: But that means you'll put people in jail.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to go right now - I want to go right now...

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Jake, may I just say...

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Jake, you brought my issue up.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: That's true. Go ahead, Christie, please.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: You know, I enjoy the interplay. Thank you, gentlemen.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I'll just say this, first off, New Jersey is the first state in the nation that now says if you are non-violent, non-dealing drug user, that you don't go to jail for your first offense. You go to mandatory treatment.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: You see, Jake, I'm pro-life. And I think you need to be pro-life for more than just the time in the womb. It gets tougher when they get out of the womb. And when they're the 16-year-old drug addict in the Florida county lockup, that life is just as precious as the life in the womb.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And so, that's why I'm for rehabilitation, why I think the war on drugs has been a failure.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: But I'll end with this. That doesn't mean we should be legalizing gate way drugs. And if Senator Paul thinks that the only victim is the person, look at the decrease in productivity, look at the way people get used and move on to other drugs when they use marijuana as a gateway drug, it is not them that are the only victims. Their families are the victims too, their children are the victims too, and their employers are the victims also.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: That's why I'll enforce the federal law, while you can still put an emphasis on rehabilitation, which we've done in New Jersey.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: May I respond?

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: Jake - Jake...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: You may respond, and then I'll bring in you, Ms. Fiorina.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Understand what they're saying. if they're going to say we are going to enforce the federal law against what the state law is, they aren't really believing in the Tenth Amendment.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Governor Christie would go into Colorado, and if you're breaking any federal law on marijuana, even though the state law allows it, he would put you in jail. If a young mother is trying to give her child cannabis oil for medical marijuana for seizure treatment, he would put her in jail, if it violates federal law.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: I would let Colorado do what the Tenth Amendment says. This power - we were never intended to have crime dealing at the federal level. Crime was supposed to be left to the states. Colorado has made their decision. And I don't want the federal government interfering and putting moms in jail, who are trying to get medicine for their kid...

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And Senator Paul knows that that's simply not the truth.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: In New Jersey, we have medical marijuana laws, which I supported and implemented. This is not medical marijuana. There's goes as much - a further step beyond. This is recreational use of marijuana.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: This is much different. And so, while he would like to use a sympathetic story to back up his point, it doesn't work. I'm not against medical marijuana. We do it in New Jersey. But I'm against the recreational use against marijuana.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: If he wants to change the federal law, get Congress to pass the law to change it, and get a president to sign it.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: May I respond? May I respond?

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Yes, Senator Paul.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: PAUL
Text: Here is the thing, he doesn't want to make it about medical marijuana, but what if New Jersey's medical marijuana contradicts the federal law? He's saying he'll send the federal government in, and he will enforce the federal law. That's not consistent with the Tenth Amendment. It is not consistent with states' rights. And it is not consistent with the conservative vision for the country.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: I don't think we should be sending the federal police in to arrest a mother and separate them from their child for giving a medicine to their child for seizures.

Speaker: PAUL
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to bring in Ms. Fiorina - I want to bring in Ms. Fiorina on this issue.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: I very much hope I am the only person on this stage who can say this, but I know there are millions of Americans out there who will say the same thing.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: My husband Frank and I buried a child to drug addiction. So, we must invest more in the treatment of drugs.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: I agree with Senator Paul. I agree with states' rights. But we are misleading young people when we tell them that marijuana is just like having a beer. It's not. And the marijuana that kids are smoking today is not the same as the marijuana that Jeb Bush smoked 40 years ago.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: We do - sorry, Barbara. We do need - we do need criminal justice reform. We have the highest incarceration rates in the world. Two-thirds of the people in our prisons are there for non-violent offenses, mostly drug related. It's clearly not working.

Speaker: FIORINA
Text: But we need to tell young people the truth. Drug addiction is an epidemic, and it is taking too many of our young people. I know this sadly from personal experience.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Hugh - Hugh, I'd like to...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Jake.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Tomorrow is - Republicans know this - tomorrow is Constitution Day. We've been talking about the 10th Amendment. Let's talk about the Second Amendment.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Governor Bush, one of the things the Supreme Court has gotten right is that it's an individual right and it's protected for individuals to hold it.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Last week, you said the next step in gun issues is to make sure they're not in the hands of mentally ill. In this state, there's a controversial law that allows guns to be taken away from people without a hearing.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Where does it go - and the problem of violence is endemic, but where does it go from what you said last week, how far into people's lives to take guns away from them?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: Not very far.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I think we need to do this state by state. There are places that get this right, and we need to make sure that we protect the privacy laws. This is a complicated place. But I do think the natural impulse on the left - Hillary Clinton, immediately after one of these horrific violent acts took place, immediately said we need to have federal gun laws. President Obama almost reflexively always says the same thing.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: And the net result is, you're going to take away rights of - of law-abiding citizens, the 99.999 percent of the people that are law- abiding citizens. That's not the right approach to do it.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: In Florida, we have a background check. We have concealed-weapon permit holders, and in fact, there's 1,200,000 of them. We have a reduction in violent crime because we put people behind bars when they use a gun in the commission of the crime. That's the better approach.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: But we're living in a society today where despair kind of grows in isolation.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: If a family member calls and says, "My child, my brother, my sister is disturbed," ought the state be able to go and get their weapon without a hearing?

Speaker: BUSH
Text: I - I think there needs to be a hearing, but the fact is, we need to encourage that kind of involvement. That's - that's exactly what we need to do.

Speaker: BUSH
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: There's a broader issue here, Hugh. And there's a broader issue here as well.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: First of all, the only people that follow the law are law-abiding people. Criminals by definition ignore the law, so you can pass all the gun laws in the world, like the left wants. The criminals are going to ignore it because they are criminals.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Here's the real issue.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: The real issue - the real issue is not what are people using to commit violence, but why are they committing the violence? And here's the truth Because you cannot separate the social, moral wellbeing of your people from their economic and other wellbeing. You cannot separate it.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: You can't have a strong country without strong people, you cannot have strong people without strong values, and you cannot have strong values without strong families and the institutions in this country that defend and support those families.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Well, and today, we have a left-wing government under this president that is undermining all of the institutions and society that support the family and teach those values.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Senator Cruz, I want to go to you.

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Your constitutional litigant (ph), are you afraid of the next- step theory of what happens to Second Amendment rights?

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: I - I am not, and - and you mentioned that the U.S. Supreme Court had rightly upheld the individual right to keep and bear arms.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: I was proud to lead 31 states before the U.S. Supreme Court defending the Second Amendment, and we won that landmark victory. And indeed, just a couple of years ago, when Harry Reid and Barack Obama came after the right to keep and bear arms of millions of Americans, I was proud to lead the fight in the United States Senate to protect our right to keep and bear arms, and for that reason...

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ... I was honored to be endorsed by Gun Owners of America...

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, Senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ... as the strongest supporter of the Second Amendment on this stage today, and I will...

Speaker: HEWITT
Text: Thank you, senator.

Speaker: CRUZ
Text: ... fight every day to defend the Bill of Rights.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I'd like to turn it over - I'd like to turn to Dana Bush.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Mr. Trump, you have said once or twice that you are really rich, and you are by far the richest person on this stage.

Speaker: BASH
Text: Chris Christie says billionaires like you and even people who make and earn far less should no longer get Social Security, or at least there should be limits based on - on their income.

Speaker: BASH
Text: You think he's wrong, and if so, why?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Speaking for myself, I'm OK with it. I think there's a certain truth to it. I know people that, frankly, it has no impact on their life whatsoever. There are many people.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I would almost say leave it up to them, but I would be willing to check it off, and say I will not get Social Security. I do not...

Speaker: BASH
Text: What about the country as a - as a policy?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: As a policy, I would almost leave it up to the people. Don't forget they pay in and they pay in, and maybe they do well, and maybe some people want it. But the fact is that there are people that truly don't need it, and there are many people that do need it very, very badly. And I would be willing to write mine off 100 percent, Dana.

Speaker: BASH
Text: So is a voluntary program the way to get the Social Security system solvent again like that.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: No, it's not. But with Donald, it's a good start. That's really good.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: No, listen. This is an issue that - that we've gotta talk about, and we haven't talked about yet.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: 71 percent of all federal spending is on entitlements and debt service. When John Kennedy was elected president in 1960, it was 26 percent.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Harvard and Dartmouth says that Social Security's going to go insolvent in seven to eight years. So what I say is very simple. We need to save this program for the good people out there who have paid into the system and need it.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: And if that means making sure that folks like Donald and many of us on the stage don't get it, that's the right thing to do because here's what Hillary Clinton is going to want to do.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: She's going to want to put more money into a system that has already lied to us and stolen from us. This government doesn't need more money to make Social Security solvent. We need to be not paying out benefits to people who don't really need it.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: We need to protect the people who Social Security means the difference between picking between heat and rent and food. That's why I put out the proposal and that's the people I'm trying to...

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I'm coming to you right now on a separate issue, sir. We received...

Speaker: (UNKNOWN)
Text: Well, I want to talk about this issue for a moment.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: We received a lot of questions from social media about climate change.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Senator Rubio, Ronald Reagan's secretary of state, George Shultz, reminds us that when Reagan was president he faced a similar situation to the one that we're facing now. There were dire warnings from the mass consensus of the scientific community about the ozone layer shrinking.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Shultz says Ronald Reagan urged skeptics in industry to come up with a plan. He said, do it as an insurance policy in case the scientists are right. The scientists were right. Reagan and his approach worked.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Secretary Shultz asks, why not take out an insurance policy and approach climate change the Reagan way?

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Because we're not going to destroy our economy the way the left-wing government that we are under now wants to do. We're not going to...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I'm citing George Shultz.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Well, and I don't - he may have lined up with their positions on this issue. But here is the bottom line. Every proposal they put forward are going to be proposals that will make it harder to do business in America, that will make it harder to create jobs in America.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Single parents are already struggling across this country to provide for their families. Maybe a billionaire here in California can afford an increase in their utility rates, but a working family in Tampa, Florida, or anywhere across this country cannot afford it.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: So we are not going to destroy our economy. We are not going to make America a harder place to create jobs in order to pursue policies that will do absolutely nothing, nothing to change our climate, to change our weather, because America is a lot of things, the greatest country in the world, absolutely.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: But America is not a planet. And we are not even the largest carbon producer anymore, China is. And they're drilling a hole and digging anywhere in the world that they can get a hold of.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: So the bottom line is, I am not in favor of any policies that make America a harder place for people to live, or to work, or to raise their families.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Governor Christie, you have said that climate change is real, and that humans help contribute to it. Without getting into the issue of China versus the United States, which I understand you've talked about before, what do you make of skeptics of climate change such as Senator Rubio?

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I don't think Senator Rubio is a skeptic of climate change. I think what Senator Rubio said I agree with. That in fact we don't need this massive government intervention to deal with the problem.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Look at what we have done in New Jersey. We have already reached our clean air goals for 2020. And when I was governor, I pulled out of the regional cap and trade deal, the only state in the Northeast that did that. And we still reached our goals.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: Why? Because 53 percent of our electricity comes from nuclear. We use natural gas. We use solar power. We're the third-highest- using solar power state. You know why? Because we made all of those things economically feasible.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I agree with Marco. We shouldn't be destroying our economy in order to chase some wild left-wing idea that somehow us by ourselves is going to fix the climate. We can contribute to that and be economically sound.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: We have proven we can do that in New Jersey. Nuclear needs to be back on the table in a significant way in this country if we want to go after this problem.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Just for the record, I was citing Secretary of State George Shultz, Ronald Reagan's secretary of state who I don't think anybody would call him left-wing.

Speaker: CHRISTIE
Text: I understand. No, no, listen, everybody makes a mistake every once in a while, Jake, even George Shultz. And if that's truly a representation of what he believes we should be doing, then with all due respect to the former secretary of state, I disagree with him.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: Jake, you mentioned me and called me a denier. Let me say, climate change...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I called you a skeptic.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: OK. A skeptic. You can measure the climate. You can measure it. That's not the issue we're discussing. Here is what I'm skeptical of. I'm skeptical of the decisions that the left wants us to make, because I know the impact those are going to have and they're all going to be on our economy.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: They will not do a thing to lower the rise of the sea. They will not do a thing to cure the drought here in California. But what they will do is they will make America a more expensive place to create jobs.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: And today with millions of people watching this broadcast that are struggling paycheck to paycheck that do not know how they're going to pay their bills at the end of this month, I'm not in favor of anything that is going to make it harder for them to raise their family.

Speaker: RUBIO
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I want to go another question right now.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: WALKER
Text: ... a lot of those people, though, and I'm going to echo what Senator Rubio just said. This is an issue where, we're talking about my state, it's thousands of manufacturing jobs. Thousands of manufacturing jobs for a rule the Obama administration, own EPA has said will have a marginal impact on climate change.

Speaker: WALKER
Text: So we're going to put thousands and thousands of jobs in my state, I think it's something like 30,000 in Ohio, other states across this country, we're going to put people - manufacturing jobs, the kind of jobs that are far greater than minimum wage, this administration is willing to put at risk for something its own EPA says is marginal (ph)...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you, Governor.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (CROSSTALK)

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I'm turning to...

Speaker: PAUL
Text: If you want a skeptic - if you want a skeptic, Jake, I will happily jump into that briar patch. If you want a real...

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: ...I'm turning to another - I'm turning to another issue right now. Senator Cruz. Well, I think we've heard from several this evening.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: A backlash against vaccines was blamed for a measles outbreak here in California. Dr. Carson, Donald Trump has publicly and repeatedly linked vaccines, childhood vaccines, to autism, which, as you know, the medical community adamantly disputes.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: You're a pediatric neurosurgeon. Should Mr. Trump stop saying this?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Well, let me put it this way, there has - there have been numerous studies, and they have not demonstrated that there is any correlation between vaccinations and autism.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: This was something that was spread widely 15 or 20 years ago, and it has not been adequately, you know, revealed to the public what's actually going on. Vaccines are very important. Certain ones. The ones that would prevent death or crippling.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: There are others, there are a multitude of vaccines which probably don't fit in that category, and there should be some discretion in those cases. But, you know, a lot of this is - is - is pushed by big government.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: And I think that's one of the things that people so vehemently want to get rid of, big government. You know, we have 4.1 million federal employees. Six hundred and fifty federal agencies and department (sic).

Speaker: CARSON
Text: That's why they have to take so much of our taxes.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Should he stop saying it? Should he stop saying that vaccines cause autism?

Speaker: CARSON
Text: Well, you know, I've just explained it to him. He can read about it if he wants to. I think he's an intelligent man and will make the correct decision after getting the real facts.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump, as president, you would...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, I - I - I'd like to respond.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: I'm going right to you.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I'd like to respond.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Mr. Trump, as president, you would be in charge of the Centers for Disease Control and the National Institutes of Health, both of which say you are wrong. How would you handle this as president?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Autism has become an epidemic. Twenty-five years ago, 35 years ago, you look at the statistics, not even close. It has gotten totally out of control.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I am totally in favor of vaccines. But I want smaller doses over a longer period of time. Because you take a baby in - and I've seen it - and I've seen it, and I had my children taken care of over a long period of time, over a two or three year period of time.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Same exact amount, but you take this little beautiful baby, and you pump - I mean, it looks just like it's meant for a horse, not for a child, and we've had so many instances, people that work for me.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Just the other day, two years old, two and a half years old, a child, a beautiful child went to have the vaccine, and came back, and a week later got a tremendous fever, got very, very sick, now is autistic.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I only say it's not - I'm in favor of vaccines, do them over a longer period of time, same amount.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But just in - in little sections.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. - Dr. Carson?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I think - and I think you're going to have - I think you're going to see a big impact on autism.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: Dr. Carson, you just heard his medical take.

Speaker: TAPPER
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: CARSON
Text: He's an OK doctor.

Speaker: CARSON
Text: (LAUGHTER)

Speaker: CARSON
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: CARSON
